gt_metadata.revision_notes: v3.0: Tier changes: GT-03: T1 -> T2; GT-05: T2 -> T3; GT-06: T2 -> T3. Previous: 2.6_corrected_2026-01-14_v3_LOCKED

ground_truth.issue: Improvements owned by Licensor - loses R&D investment
key_elements: All improvements to Licensed IP developed by Licensee become Licensor property
Licensee loses R&D investment entirely
Creates disincentive to innovate
Should negotiate Licensee ownership of improvements
Alternative: Joint ownership with license-back
Licensor should pay for Licensee-developed improvements
ground_truth.contract_text: Improvements to the Licensed IP developed by Licensee shall be owned by Licensor.

key_elements: Licensor liability capped at 12 months royalties only
Royalties may be low in early years (Year 1 = $0 running royalty possible)
No carve-outs for IP title failure
No carve-outs for willful misconduct
Increase to 24+ months or fixed minimum floor
Add carve-outs for IP warranty breach
ground_truth.contract_text: LICENSOR'S TOTAL LIABILITY SHALL NOT EXCEED THE ROYALTIES PAID IN THE TWELVE MONTHS PRECEDING THE CLAIM.

ground_truth.issue: Mandatory minimum royalty regardless of sales
key_elements: $250K minimum royalty from Year 2
Payable regardless of actual Net Sales
Running royalties credited against minimum
Creates significant fixed cost even if IP proves uncommercial
Should reduce minimum amount or phase in gradually
Add adjustment for market conditions or force majeure
Allow credit for marketing/development expenses
ground_truth.contract_text: Beginning in Year 2, Licensee shall pay minimum annual royalty of $250,000, regardless of actual Net Sales. Running royalties shall be credited against this minimum.

key_elements: Licensed IP provided AS-IS
Only warranty is 9.1 (right to grant + non-infringement 'to knowledge')
'To knowledge' qualifier weakens non-infringement warranty
No express warranty of functionality or commercial viability
No warranty of fitness for Field of Use
Should strengthen to unconditional non-infringement
Add functionality warranty for patent claims
ground_truth.contract_text: Licensor represents it has the right to grant the license and, to its knowledge, the Licensed IP does not infringe third-party rights. EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH HEREIN, THE LICENSED IP IS PROVIDED "AS IS" WITHOUT WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND.

key_elements: 10% of Net Sales is above typical rates for consumer electronics (usually 2-5%)
May compress Licensee margins significantly
Should negotiate lower rate or tiered structure
Consider volume discounts at higher sales levels
Review industry benchmarks for comparable IP
ground_truth.contract_text: Licensee shall pay Licensor a royalty equal to ten percent (10%) of Net Sales of Licensed Products, payable quarterly within thirty (30) days following the end of each calendar quarter.

key_elements: Prior written consent required for any sublicenses
Could limit business model flexibility
May restrict contract manufacturing arrangements
Should add automatic affiliate sublicensing right
Consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed
Pre-approved sublicensee categories for manufacturing
ground_truth.contract_text: Licensee may grant sublicenses with Licensor's prior written consent.

key_elements: Neither party liable for indirect/consequential damages
Blocks recovery for lost profits if IP fails or is invalid
Should add carve-outs for IP title failure
Carve-outs for willful misconduct
Carve-outs for breach of exclusivity
ground_truth.contract_text: NEITHER PARTY SHALL BE LIABLE FOR INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES.

key_elements: 10-year term with no TfC right
Only exit is termination for cause (60-day cure)
Locked in even if IP proves commercially unviable
Should add TfC with 12-month notice after Year 3
Consider annual opt-out after initial commitment period
Allow exit if minimum royalties become unsustainable
ground_truth.contract_text: This Agreement shall continue for ten (10) years from the Effective Date, unless earlier terminated. [No termination for convenience provision exists]

key_elements: $500K upfront license fee is non-refundable
Significant sunk cost if IP proves unusable
Standard for exclusive IP licenses but still a risk
Could negotiate partial refund if IP fails validity challenge
Consider escrow until first commercial use
ground_truth.contract_text: Upon execution, Licensee shall pay a non-refundable upfront license fee of $500,000.

key_elements: Licensor can audit annually
Licensee bears audit costs if underpayment exceeds 5%
5% threshold is relatively low
Should increase threshold to 10%
Add cap on audit frequency
Require reasonable advance notice
ground_truth.contract_text: Licensor may audit Licensee's books and records once per year upon reasonable notice. Licensor bears audit costs unless underpayment exceeds 5%, in which case Licensee bears costs.

ground_truth.issue: Licensed IP schedule (Exhibit A) not attached - undefined scope
key_elements: Exhibit A is blank - states '[Patent and trademark schedule to be attached]'
Licensed IP definition (1.2) references Exhibit A for scope
Client cannot know what IP they are licensing
Value of exclusivity cannot be assessed
Creates fundamental uncertainty about contract scope
Must require populated schedule before execution
ground_truth.contract_text: 1.2 'Licensed IP' means the patents, trademarks, trade secrets, and proprietary technology described in Exhibit A. [...] EXHIBIT A - LICENSED INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY [Patent and trademark schedule to be attached]

ground_truth.issue: Territory definition (Exhibit B) not attached - exclusivity meaningless
key_elements: Exhibit B is blank - states '[Territory definition to be attached]'
License grant (2.1) is exclusive within 'Territory'
Exclusivity has no meaning without defined geographic scope
Cannot assess market value or competitive protection
Must require populated schedule before execution
ground_truth.contract_text: 2.1 Grant. Licensor grants Licensee an exclusive license to use the Licensed IP within the Field of Use and Territory during the Term. [...] EXHIBIT B - TERRITORY [Territory definition to be attached]

ground_truth.issue: No IP infringement indemnification from Licensor
key_elements: No indemnification clause exists in the agreement
Licensee exposed to third-party infringement claims
If Licensed IP infringes, Licensee bears defense costs and damages
Standard provision in commercial IP licenses
Should add Licensor indemnity for IP infringement claims
Include defense obligation, settlement control, and hold-harmless
ground_truth.contract_text: N/A - No indemnification provision exists. Contract contains only 9.1 warranty ('to its knowledge, the Licensed IP does not infringe') but no indemnification for breach.

ground_truth.issue: Confidentiality Survival Inadequate for Trade Secrets
key_elements: 5-year survival period for confidentiality
IP license involves trade secrets, manufacturing know-how, proprietary technology
Trade secrets have indefinite commercial value
5 years insufficient for competitive protection post-termination
Should add perpetual protection for trade secrets
Should differentiate trade secrets from general confidential info
ground_truth.contract_text: 8.1 Confidentiality. Each Party shall maintain the confidentiality of all Confidential Information. This obligation survives termination for five (5) years.

ground_truth.issue: Non-infringement warranty qualified 'to knowledge' - inadequate for IP license
key_elements: 9.1 only warrants non-infringement 'to Licensor's knowledge'
Knowledge qualifier shifts due diligence burden to Licensee
Licensor should know their own IP portfolio and freedom to operate
If Licensee faces infringement claim, 'knowledge' defense is worthless
Should be unconditional non-infringement warranty
Or require Licensor to have conducted clearance search
Critical for commercial IP license - T1 issue
ground_truth.contract_text: 9.1 Licensor represents it has the right to grant the license and, to its knowledge, the Licensed IP does not infringe third-party rights.

issues: GT-02 (12.2 - Licensor liability cap too low)

v2.1_changes: REMOVED old GT-09 (10.2 Enforcement split) - 50/50 after costs is market standard for exclusive licenses
Demoted No TfC from T2 to T2 (kept) - still material but 10-year terms are common in IP
Demoted upfront fee to T3 - $500K non-refundable is standard for exclusive IP licenses
Added GT-10 (7.1 Audit threshold) as T3 - 5% threshold is aggressive but minor
contract_verification: 7.1 verified: 'Licensor bears audit costs unless underpayment exceeds 5%'
10.2 verified: 'remainder shared equally' - removed as market standard
13.1 verified: '10 years' with only 13.2 cause-based termination
items_removed: Original GT-09 (10.2 Enforcement recovery) - 50/50 split after costs is standard; Licensee bears market harm but also benefits from enforcement
